Ça fait 100 ans qu'a eu lieu les émeutes: A hundred years ago, the Quebec city conscription riots took place. During the Easter weekend of 1918, for 5 days, the city is on the edge as violence escalates: citizens rebel, newspapers' offices are ransacked and the army shoots the crowd. To this day, it is one of the most important political crisis in the province of Quebec.
Cet épisode méconnu mérite d'être mis en: These overlooked events deserve a better recognition
<p>Le Canada est en guerre. C'est la Pre:
Since 1914, Canada is at war in the First World War.

To replenish the army's ranks, devastated by the fighting on European battlefields, the federal governement implements conscription.
<p>Dès 1916 à Québec, des échauffourées:
Starting in 1916, there are skirmishes between the citizens of Quebec city and the army's recruiters. Citizens accuse the governement of anglicizing the army and favouring English Canadian officers.

Anger spreads throughout the province: newspapers supporting conscription are ransacked and numerous demonstrations ensue. Tension reaches its peak when Montreal Star's owner's house is destroyed with dynamite.
<p>Le prix du pain a doublé, la viande,:
Bread price has doubled, while meat price has tripled and potatoes, a staple of many of households diet, has increased fivefolds.

Moreover, the government closes Ross arms factory, counting more than 2,000 employees. The economical situation is catastrophic.
Qui participe aux&nbsp;émeutes&nbsp;?: Who takes part in the riots?
<p>La classe populaire se retrouve en ba:
Working class meets in the Lower Town. The majority of workers in factories and shipyards are French speaker and only about 15% are Catholic English, mostly Irish.

They are young and prone to enrollment.
Le droit de vote... pour certaines femme: The right to vote… for certain women
<p>Une élection a lieu en 1917. Afin d'a: An election is held in 1917. To ensure conscription’s victory, conservatives remove the right to vote to conscientious objectors and Canadian citizens born in enemy states and naturalized after 1902.
<p>Le gouvernement conservateur souhaite:
Conservative government wishes to form a coalition with the Liberal party refuses, objecting conscription.

Liberals win 82 seats, of which 62 are in Quebec, leaving only 3 seats to the Conservatives.

The country is so divided, a Liberal deputy submits a motion to have the province of Quebec leave the Canadian confederation. However, it is short-lived and quickly removed.
<p>Le contexte international est favorab:
The international context favors anti-imperialism.

The Mexican revolution is ongoing, but more importantly, Russia has just capitulated following the Bolchevik revolution. Mutineries in the French army increases fears.

Ireland is also confronted with a strong and rising movement for independence.
Ne manque qu'une&nbsp;étincelle: All it takes is a spark
<p>Tout commence à Saint-Roch le jeudi 2:
Everything starts in Saint-Roch on Thursday, March 28th 1918. The bowling in the Cercle Frontenac, on the Jacques-Cartier, place is lively.

Hundreds of youths play bowling.
<p>Tout se passe comme si une digue étai: It all happens as if there was a sudden breach and nothing could stop the population’s anger
<p>La population se réunit une nouvelle:
The population meets once again for a day of protests against conscription. Trouble begins in the afternoon.

This time, the army is ready for a fight.
<p>Les églises sont pleines pour la mess:
Churches are full for Sunday’s Easter Mass. A letter from the cardinal is read, condemning the mobs

Many priests go against the order and denounce the army’s actions.
<p>Contrairement aux termes de l’entente: Soldiers are now more present than ever in the streets, contrary to the terms of the agreement with Lavergne.
<p>Bilan des opérations chez les insurgé: A dark count on the insurgent side : four men killed and about 70 hurt.
<p>Des témoins à l’enquête du coroner ré:
At the coroner’s investigation, witnesses reveal the bullets used by the soldiers were forbidden.

They are explosive bullets and are more lethal than military bullets
<p>Le premier ministre conservateur Bord:
Conservative Prime minister Borden fears the hopes fostered by the Bolshevik revolution in Russia

What better way than a bloodbath to deter sympathy towards the communist insurrection in the working class?

Besides, starting in 1919, the country is shaken by one of the greatest strike of its history in Winnipeg.
<p>Il s’agit de l’une des 3 plus importa:
The events in Quebec city are among the three most important military interventions in the province of Quebec, alongside the Oka crisis and the events of October 1970.

World War I will cause 9 millions deaths and 20 millions hurt. It is dubbed the last of the last, meaning it is the last of the last wars: in French, “La Der des Ders”.
<p>Québec, Printemps 1918 est le titre d:
Quebec, Spring 1918 is the title of a sculpture created by Aline Martineau to commemorate the riots.

Inaugurated on September 4 1998, it is erected at the corner the streets Saint-Vallier, Saint-Joseph and Bagot, in the Saint-Sauveur neighbourhood.
